subject: Design
title: The System Usability Scale: Measuring UX in 10 Questions
description: A tiny lesson with a big payoff: The System Usability Scale: Measuring UX in 10 Questions.

hook.text: In 1986, John Brooke created a 10-question survey that became the world's most used UX measurement tool.

buildup.text: The System Usability Scale (SUS) asks users to rate 10 statements. The score reveals overall perceived usability.

discovery.text: A SUS score above 68 is above average. Below 50 means serious usability problems. It takes just 5 minutes.

twist.text: Brooke created SUS as a quick hack. He never published it formally â€” it spread by word of mouth for decades.

climax.text: SUS proves that measuring experience doesn't require complexity â€” just the right questions.

punchline.text: The best UX metric was never formally published. It just worked.
